docs.lead_paragraph: IN the 70's, when condominiums and co-ops were unregulated in Connecticut, certain caveats relating to ownership in some of them with modest-income purchasers were hidden in plain sight in the small print of sale contracts. Seemingly innocuous and entirely legal, the language indicated a leasehold on the land -- rather than outright ownership, a grenade that buyers and even their lawyers failed to spot well into the 80's.

headline.main: In the Region/Connecticut; Landlord Leaseholds Troubling Condos and Co-ops

docs.lead_paragraph: A large and apparently growing chorus of New Jerseyans are nervous and bitter about the drive for lower taxes and less government in the Whitman administration. They are the state employees. It used to be said that public workers accepted low salaries for high job security, but in New Jersey, public employees' salaries are often higher than in the new, depressed wage, post-industrial service sector, and their job security is dwindling every day. Now Governor Whitman wants to privatize 25 Department of Motor Vehicles offices, the ones that handle paperwork for car titles, licenses and so on. She also wants to close North Princeton Developmental Center and the Marlboro Psychiatric Hospital, sending their patients to, yes, private, nonprofit institutions. About 350 motor vehicle workers would pass from the public to the private sector, while some 2,000 mental health workers could be out of jobs entirely.

docs.lead_paragraph: MITCHELL WEISSBERG can tell a lot about a marriage by how a couple picks out a kitchen faucet. "Some people can't rationalize why the other person needs to spend $300 on a faucet when they can get one for $75," said Mr. Weissberg, vice president of Krup's Kitchen and Bath in New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Except for his tactically inept proposal to balance the budget in 10 years, President Clinton has played the budget game pretty cannily for a person who lacks the votes to impose his will on Congress. Debate driven by the warring ambitions of Bob Dole, Phil Gramm and Newt Gingrich has brought the brutality of the Republican plan into full view. But voters will eventually demand more of their President than deft tactics or a clever re-election strategy. Mr. Clinton will have to present a principled reason why they should care if he wins re-election. He must answer then, definitively, whether he agrees with Speaker Gingrich et al that the budget must be balanced soon and, if so, at what pain.

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco Inc. said yesterday that it had withdrawn its offer to acquire all the publicly traded shares of the Bankers Life Holding Corporation for $22 a share but that its board had approved buying up to 10 million shares on the open market. Conseco, which is based in Carmel, Ind., and provides finacial services to life insurance companies, already owns 63.2 percent of the 52.8 million shares outstanding in Bankers, which sells mostly health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: In what could be a first step toward a revolutionary change in Government economic policy, the Senate today approved a Republican road map that is supposed to put the Government on the course to a balanced Federal budget in seven years. After a week of highly partisan debate and votes on more than 50 amendments, most of them generally along party lines, the proposed budget calling for nearly $1 trillion in savings by 2002 was approved 57 to 42. The House endorsed a similar blueprint last week. All Republicans and three Democrats -- Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Sam Nunn of Georgia and Charles S. Robb of Virginia -- voted for the measure today. The remaining Democrats voted "no."

headline.kicker: SENATE APPROVES PROPOSAL TO BALANCE BUDGET BY 2002

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal agents conducted raids in 31 states today after a year-and-a-half investigation intended to break up syndicates that stage automobile accidents and defraud health insurers. Agents began arresting 126 people and were searching 22 locations. Some of the 126 were named in indictments returned today; others were the subject of criminal complaints filed by the bureau.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Senate moved toward a vote on Wednesday on a general framework for Government spending over the next seven years, Democratic senators tried to score politically by forcing Republicans into uncomfortable votes against popular health and education programs. Republicans stuck together and voted down the Democratic amendments on party-line votes. Democrats are hoping the Republicans' discipline will backfire in the elections next year.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 100 health maintenance organizations are bidding this week for a chance to offer standardized health coverage to 240,000 employees of 10 big companies. The bidding is the employers' latest effort to push the H.M.O.'s to lower prices and let employer groups monitor the care provided by doctors and hospitals. By banding together and offering $1 billion in combined buying power in 27 markets, the 10 employers hope to duplicate the successes of regional employer coalitions in a growing number of metropolitan areas, notably Minneapolis and San Francisco.
